ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
DMC  –  developing member country 
GIS  –  geographic information system 
PARD  –  Pacific Department 
TA  –  technical assistance 
TASF  –  Technical Assistance Special Fund 
 
 
GLOSSARY 
 
adaptation pathways  –  A  planning  approach  addressing  the  uncertainty  and 
  challenges of climate change decision-making. It enables 
consideration of multiple possible futures and allows analysis 
and/or exploration of the robustness and flexibility of various 
options across those multiple futures. 
climate change  –  A response to climate change that involves adjusting to actual 
adaptation  or expected future climate. The goal is to reduce risks to the 
harmful  effects  of  climate  change,  like  sea-level 
encroachment, more intense extreme weather events, or food 
insecurity. 
climate change  –  The  ability  to  anticipate,  prepare  for,  and  respond  to 
resilience  hazardous events, trends, or disturbances related to climate. 
Improving  climate  resilience  involves  (i)  assessing  how 
climate change will create new climate-related risks or alter 
current ones and (ii) taking steps to better cope with these 
risks. 
geographic  –  A  computer  system  for  capturing,  storing,  checking,  and 
information system  displaying data related to positions on Earth's surface. By 
relating seemingly unrelated data, a geographic information 
system (GIS) can help individuals and organizations better 
understand spatial patterns and relationships. 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA), Support to Climate  Resilient 
Investment Pathways in the Pacific, will support the efforts of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
in scaling up its investment in climate change adaptation in all 14 Pacific developing member 
countries (DMCs).1 It will do so by building on past and ongoing ADB efforts in the Pacific. These 
efforts include climate-proofing infrastructure investments; supporting the development of small-
value renewable energy projects for mitigating emissions; designing water sector adaptation 
investments; facilitating greater flows of climate finance into the region; providing a range of 
financial  products  for  disaster  and  emergency assistance, from  initial  disaster  response to 
recovery and reconstruction; and supporting policy and capacity development interventions to 
reduce climate change and disaster risks.2 
 
2.  The TA is included in the regional operations business plan for the Pacific, 2020–2022.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  A recent review of ADB’s current climate risk assessment system identified a need to shift 
ADB support further upstream to enable a more strategic analysis of climate risks and climate 
programming at the country, thematic, and sector levels.4 To date, the system has primarily 
focused on project-specific support, which is still necessary but needs to take on a more holistic 
approach to better help the DMCs respond to growing climate threats.  
 
4.  ADB and its Pacific DMCs need an upstream and multifaceted approach for several 
reasons, including 
 
(i)  the multitude of climate change threats facing Pacific countries, including rising 
sea levels and associated coastal inundation and erosion, more intense cyclones 
and extreme rainfall events, longer droughts, and weakened marine ecosystems 
from bleaching and acidification;5  
(ii)  the  immediacy  of  the  risks,  including  the  lack  of  fresh  water  in  low-lying 
communities, with sea incursions polluting once-reliable water sources;  
(iii)  recent evidence suggesting that sea level rise is accelerating faster than previous 
projections, because of rapid melting of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets;6   
(iv)  the multifaceted impacts of climate change, including economic and financial 
impacts (sovereign credit profiles are already being influenced by climate extremes, 
and markets are starting to price-in future climate change);

be initiated only after a no-objection letter has been obtained from the government.

(v)  the wide-ranging, immediate, and exacerbating impacts of climate change that 
accentuate existing vulnerabilities in Pacific countries because of their small size, 
isolation, narrow economic bases, limited resources, and dependence on trade; 
and  
(vi)  the small likelihood that Pacific DMCs on their own will address planned adaptation, 
because many barriers (including information, economic, financial and investment 
barriers) make it difficult to plan and implement adaptation actions; thus, barrier 
removal provides a strong justification for ADB to support DMCs in strategic 
climate resilience planning.  
 
5.  The Pacific DMCs are scaling up infrastructure investments, which adds urgency to 
broadening ADB’s approach. It is vital that these investments steer the Pacific towards greater 
resilience. A new approach to project design and development in the Pacific will reflect ADB’s 
overall commitment to provide $80 billion from 2019 to 2030 to combat climate change. 
 
6.  The TA’s strategic, multifaceted, and risk-informed approach will support country and 
regional  commitments  to  climate  change  adaptation  measures,  while  integrating  into  the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) economic recovery efforts.7 This approach will also align with 
Strategy 2030.8 In particular, it will help advance the four Strategy 2030 components under ADB’s 
operational priority three (Table 1). To varying degrees, it will also support resilience (the third 
Strategy 2030 component), cutting across the other six operational priorities (Table 2).

3 
7.  In addition, the TA will advance the draft Pacific Approach 2021–2025, support the Asian 
Development Fund’s focus on small island developing states and its thematic priorities that 
include climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction, and aid ADB’S alignment with the 
Paris Agreement in accordance with the methodology currently under development.9 
 
8.  The TA will also apply lessons learned from previous ADB projects that helped build 
climate resilience in the Pacific.10 These lessons include: 
 
(i)  Opportunities exist to reduce future risk from sea level rise and extreme events, 
but action must be taken now to build adaptation and resilience into planning 
processes. 
(ii)  A greater understanding of the barriers to long-term adaptation is needed if holistic 
and strategic responses to climate change are to be defined and planned. 
(iii)  Climate change adaptation must be better mainstreamed into national and sector 
development planning to ensure that adaptation interventions are not developed 
and implemented as stand-alone projects. 
(iv)  Climate change and disaster risk assessment further upstream (e.g., as part of 
country programming) can help inform the type and location of future investments. 
(v)  Geospatial climate and disaster risk information can greatly improve this upstream 
assessment, thereby strengthening risk-based decision-making. 
(vi)  More consistent efforts are required to build the capacity of government agencies 
in climate change adaptation (e.g., augmenting capacity through consultants on a 
per project basis has had a limited impact). 
 
9.  Finally, the TA will build on approaches developed and implemented by the Adaptation 
and Land Use Working Group, ADB’s working group on geographic information system (GIS), 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Thematic Group, Sustainable Development and Climate 
Change  Department,  Private  Sector  Operations  Department,  and  ADB’s  other  regional 
departments. These approaches include the lessons from the Sustainable Development and 
Climate  Change  Department’s  Pilot  Program  for  Climate  Resilience,  which  established 
programmatic approaches to climate change adaptation and resilience-building, in particular the 
development of robust pipelines of investments.11 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: resilience to climate change impacts and 
associated  risks  in  Pacific  DMCs  improved  across  built  infrastructure,  ecosystems  and 
communities.12 The TA will have the following outcome: systemic resilient adaptation pathways in 
the Pacific increased.

B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  Output 1: Access to climate change information improved for strategic decision-
making. Accurate, timely, and relevant information saves decision-makers both time and money 
through  increased  efficiency,  improved  productivity,  and  rapid  deployment  of  innovations. 
For instance, multi-hazard assessments that model future climate change impacts can help inform 
strategic decision-making to support long-term adaptation, such as steering population and asset 
growth away from exposed areas. Under this output, ADB will pursue two strategies, as follows. 
 
12.  The first strategy is to analyze key barriers to long-term adaptation. ADB will seek to 
identify the full range of economic, political, social, and governance barriers in its Pacific DMCs, 
as well as benefits and opportunities that adaptation would bring to Pacific DMCs. To optimize 
synergies, this  analysis  can  be  conducted  in conjunction  with  assessments  by the  Pacific 
Department (PARD) for fragile and conflict-affected situations. From this analysis, ADB will help 
Pacific DMCs better define and justify differentiated measures to address the physical, economic, 
and financial risks of climate change (under output 2 below).  
 
13.  The second strategy is to expand access to data on climate change and disaster risks. In 
coordination with other development partners working across the region, the Pacific Regional 
Infrastructure  Facility,13 and  ongoing  work  under  the  Pacific  Disaster  Resilience  Program 
(footnote 10), ADB will explore options for a consistent regional approach and tool to collect, 
analyze, and store geospatial climate and disaster risk information, including information on the 
exposure and vulnerability of infrastructure and development assets. The ultimate goal of this 
strategy is to help Pacific DMCs evaluate and use such information to develop investments that 
support both long-term adaptation to climate change and community resilience to natural hazards. 
Specific interventions will be determined through consultations and close collaboration with the 
ADB GIS Working Group, the Urban Climate Change and Resilient Trust Fund Spatial Data 
Analysis Explorer, and regional partners.14 The TA will prioritize support for climate modeling and 
multi-hazard disaster risk assessment studies in conjunction with PARD management and Pacific 
DMC governments.  
 
14.  Output 2: Planning and policy development processes enhanced to better adapt to 
a changing climate. Building on the two strategies employed under output 1, this output will help 
Pacific DMCs pursue a portfolio of strategic resilience measures to address rising climate risks, 
with complementary approaches to address financial and economic risks. The three strategies to 
achieve output 2 will be implemented with the recognition that there is no single approach to 
climate change adaptation in the Pacific. Additionally, these strategies will work in synergy with 
ADB’s Pacific Disaster Resilience Program and associated TA.15  
 
 
13  ADB.  Pacific  Region  Infrastructure  Facility  Coordination  Office-Leveraging  Infrastructure  for  Sustainable 
Development.  
14 Regional partners include Australia’s Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Commonwealth Scientific and 
Industrial Research Organisation, Japan’s Asia Pacific Adaptation Information Platform, New Zealand’s Ministry of 
Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Pacific Catastrophe Risk Insurance Company, the Pacific Community, the Pacific 
Regional Environment Programme, and World Bank. 
15 In ten participating Pacific countries, the program provides contingent financing (in the form of loans and grants) 
associated with short-term, post-disaster, and early recovery financing needs, while the associated TA supports 
priority long-term disaster risk management activities to strengthen the resilience of institutions and communities.

5 
15.  The third strategy is to formulate adaptation pathways to increase long-term resilience.16 
ADB will help DMCs pursue an iterative adaptation pathways approach to address the root causes 
of exposure and vulnerability to climate change.17 Because of the uncertainty of projections, this 
involves planning a range of immediate, medium, and long-term adaptation strategies across 
multiple sectors, with a cycle of review and updates.18 If done holistically, such an approach can 
provide a strong economic justification for sound long-term investments by considering factors 
such as sovereign creditworthiness, stranded assets, and cascading impacts. In addition, working 
in collaboration with PARD’s sector divisions, the TA should ensure that investments do not lock 
economies into maladaptive pathways that are difficult and costly to change later.  
  
16.  The fourth strategy is to develop capital investment plans for resilient infrastructure and 
services. Following the programmatic approach implemented under the Pilot Program for Climate 
Resilience (footnote 11), the adaptation strategies developed under the third strategy will be used 
to  help  develop  integrated  multisectoral  capital  investment  plans  to  inform  ADB  country 
programming. The plans will identify high-priority “type 2” green and gray investments and can 
also screen out investment projects that do not contribute to resilience.19 Developing these plans 
will  involve  multistakeholder  engagement  processes,  including  community  level  adaptation 
actions.20 In these efforts, ADB will seek to leverage increased levels of external climate finance, 
continuing efforts to access climate finance from bilateral and multilateral sources, such as the 
Green Climate Fund.   
 
17.  The fifth strategy is to support policy development and capacity building at the national 
level. ADB will promote mainstreaming climate change  adaptation into national and sector 
development planning by integrating climate change adaptation strategies into current policy, 
planning, and development efforts, rather than addressing it through stand-alone projects or 
programs. ADB will engage with ministries in charge of finance and economic planning, together 
with climate change, environment, and sector ministries to (i) leverage efforts associated with 
existing development budgets, (ii) address identified barriers to long-term adaptation, and (iii) shift 
national plans and financial management to align with an adaptation pathways approach. ADB 
will strengthen links with the nationally determined contributions and national adaptation plans 
under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change agreements.21  
 
 
16 M. Haasnoot et al. 2013. Dynamic adaptive policy pathways: A method for crafting robust decisions for a deeply 
uncertain world. Global Environmental Change. Volume 23 (issue no. 2). pages 485-498. 
17  This approach is consistent with climate risk informed decision analysis, which is applied in the water sector and 
promoted by the Alliance for Global Water Adaptation. 
18 Whenever possible, these strategies will align with ADB’s efforts to promote low-carbon growth in its Pacific DMCs, 
particularly in the areas of transport, urban development, and clean energy. Clean energy includes ongoing ADB 
support to develop small-value renewable energy projects in the Pacific, which increases resilience by reducing 
dependence on imported diesel-fueled electricity generation. Since adaptation solutions are site-dependent, local 
planning  decisions  must  be  tailored  to  local  conditions,  with  three  main  strategies  available—protecting, 
accommodating, and retreating. Measures can start with no- and low-regret options, which have favorable benefit-
to-cost ratios, and investments can then be sequenced over time. Decision makers can use “trigger points” (e.g., sea 
level rise above a certain point) to account for uncertainty in projections. 
19  The main objective of type 2 adaptation activities is to address climate change risks. This contrasts with type 1 
adaptation, which consists of incremental measures to “climate proof” infrastructure. Gray investments can either 
support the construction of new assets or the rehabilitation of existing assets. Green investments could include 
restoring forests, mangroves, and wetlands. 
20  Building from COVID-19 response, social protection measures could include improved community preparedness for 
climate change and extreme weather events. 
21  The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change is an international environmental treaty addressing 
climate change, negotiated and signed by 154 states at the United Nations Conference on Environment and 
Development, informally known as the Earth Summit, held in Rio de Janeiro from 3 to 14 June 1992.

6 
18.  Output 3: Projects and programs supported, with focus on upstream inputs and 
partnership building. ADB will strive to improve its support to projects and programs in the 
Pacific. Whether through project-level assessments or regional partnerships, the goal of this 
output is to promote climate resilient approaches throughout the region.  
 
19.  The sixth strategy is to integrate climate and disaster risks into project designs. At the 
project level, ADB will continue to refine its approach to climate risk and adaptation assessments. 
Risk assessments should be integrated from the start of project conceptualization, based on the 
latest scientific findings and projections. The TA will provide support to integrate quality climate 
and disaster risk assessment and emissions reduction analysis into project preparation processes, 
especially for projects that receive grant financing under the Asian Development Fund 13 thematic 
pool on climate adaptation and disaster risk reduction. It will also conduct assessments on the 
Paris  Alignment.22 Downstream  implementation  of  climate  risk  management  will  also  be 
strengthened by enabling more flexible and iterative adaptation and risk reduction interventions 
and improving mechanisms for monitoring, evaluation and learning.  
 
20.  The seventh strategy is to strengthen regional capacity through knowledge sharing, 
partnerships, and policy dialogue. ADB will seek to strengthen the knowledge, skills, and practices 
of government agencies that have responsibility for climate change and disaster risk management. 
In these efforts, ADB will look to develop and strengthen regional networks, policy dialogues and 
peer-to-peer learning, in partnership with regional organizations, development partners, civil 
society, and private sector organizations. A focus will be on promoting gender-transformative 
approaches, which directly seek to change conditions and practices that perpetuate gender 
inequalities and relations of power between men or women.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $2.0 million, of which $1.0 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources) and $1.0 million will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Climate Change Fund. The key expenditure items are listed 
in Appendix 2. The TA activities outlined in paras. 12–20 are eligible for Climate Change Fund 
financing according to para. 16 of its implementation guidelines revised in August 2020.23 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
22.  ADB, through PARD’s Energy Division, will be the executing agency and will exercise 
overall responsibility for coordination, supervision, and implementation of all TA activities, while 
the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department will provide technical support. 
The TA will be monitored principally through biannual progress reports. 
 
23.  The Energy Division will supervise and oversee recruitment of an international consulting 
firm and individual consultants. A firm will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based selection 
method with a 90:10 quality–cost ratio through simplified technical proposal. Three climate 
change and disaster risk management specialists (two international and one national), one 
international climate change scientist, and one national project coordinator will be recruited 
following ADB’s individual consultant selection. Over its course, the TA may require additional  
international climate change and disaster risk management specialists; experts in the field of

concurrence of the Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial Management Department. 
 
26.  The estimated inputs will be up to 120 person-months of international and national 
consultants over 60 months. The exact requirements will vary according to the scope of work and 
studies. Resource persons may also be recruited as facilitators at workshops. ADB staff involved 
with the TA may participate as resource persons in knowledge sharing events, which will include 
requesting feedback and suggestions on improving the activities being implemented under the 
TA. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
The consultants will procure works and goods (as applicable).

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
28.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Support to Climate Resilient Investment Pathways in the Pacific, and hereby reports this action 
to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
1. Output 1: Access to climate change information improved for strategic decision-making 
1.1 Develop plan for supporting regional portal and platform on climate risks with partners (regional agencies, 
development partners, multilateral development banks). (by Q2 2021) 
1.2 Conduct regional or country-level studies on barriers to long-term adaptation. (by Q4 2021) 
1.3 Conduct GIS-spatial analysis on climate risks. (by Q2 2022)  
1.4 Collaborate with partners (regional agencies, development partners, multilateral development banks) to collect 
hazard and risk data that will be accessible to project teams and DMCs over the long-term. (starting Q3 2022) 
 
2. Output 2: Planning and policy development processes enhanced to better adapt to a changing climate 
2.1 Engage with Pacific DMCs in adaptation pathways mapping to identify immediate, medium, and long-term 
adaptation strategies. (by Q1 2022) 
2.2 Support policy development and capacity building to shift national plans and financial management to align with an 
adaptation pathways approach. (by Q2 2022) 
2.3 Support development of integrated multisectoral capital investment plans that identify high-priority projects. (by Q1 
2023) 
2.4 Develop proposals to attract external climate finance in support of capital investment plans. (by Q2 2023)  
 
3. Output 3: Projects and programs supported, with focus on upstream inputs and partnership building 
3.1 Provide support to project teams to develop and integrate quality climate and disaster risk assessment into the 
project preparation processes. (starting Q1 2021) 
3.2 Develop and strengthen regional networks and policy dialogues, in partnership with regional organizations, 
development partners, civil society, and private sector organizations. (starting Q3 2021) 
3.3 Promote gender-transformative approaches, which directly seek to change conditions and practices that perpetuate 
gender inequalities. (starting Q3 2021)
